word.item: Every night he would come into (this) town and swallow two or three people.
The Indians would kill him but in four days he would come to life again.
He would come into the town every night.
(And) every night he would swallow (some of) the people.
When night came, he would sing.
Every night he would come and swallow two or three people.
Every night when the sun was going down, he would sing again.
Now a young man was courting a young woman.
Then, taking her with him, he went home.
She thought he was a human being (but) he was not a human being.

morph.item: to raise children, plants or animals

word.item: But it turned out that they were half beast.

morph.item: concessive postfix "even if, even though, though"

word.item: “someday if you grow up, it will be a good thing if you go to see your relatives,” she would say.
When they grew up, they were feathering arrows.

morph.item: preverb "up, down," also used as a resultative

word.item: When they had feathered all of (their) arrows and had tied them together they stood up holding them.
“If you go straight over there in the woods, you will find the town,” she said.
Now they were going into the woods.
All day long they were walking (along).
When night came, they lay down.
The next day they went on again.
When they got halfway into the woods, a cardinal whistled.
One of the brothers said, “If you shoot it, it will be a good thing,” he told him.

morph.item: to try - ONLY if preceded by "-wan" (idomatic)

word.item: The other one strung his bow and was about to shoot the bird (when) the cardinal spoke to him. The cardinal spoke.
“If I tell you (two) something worthwhile, it will be a good thing,” he said.
The owl-mammoth has swallowed all of your relatives.
All of the houses are (still) standing, but (there) are no people (in them).
Now if you go and see, it will be a good thing," he said.
If you proceed straight into the woods, you will find the town,” he said.

morph.item: they all (3F-MP) lay, lie, are lying

word.item: They walked on and when they got near the clearing, (they saw) the houses standing (there).
When they got into the town, (there) were no people at all.
They came out (of the woods) and went on into the town.
When they got to the middle of the town, one house (had) smoke.
When they got to the house (that had) smoke, (they found) Old Toad woman living (there).
When they came to her house, she was glad.
Nevertheless, your relatives are no more,” she said.
“The owl-mammoth has swallowed them and killed them.
He still comes every night and swallows me, but he throws me up again,” she said.
Nevertheless, the (owl-)mammoth will swallow you tonight,” she said.

morph.item: to place in a horizontal position

word.item: When they had gathered enough wood, they cut two logs and placed them close together.

morph.item: they two (3MD) lay, lie, are lying

word.item: It looked like a bed where two people were lying.
Now Old Toad Woman spoke to them.
“When the sun gets red, the owl-mammoth always comes here singing,” she said.
It turned out that way; when the sun got red, the mammoth was coming singing.
Now it was almost night, (and) when it was getting dark, he came out of the woods.
(The boys) kindled a fire in front of (the place) where they had made the bed.
The fire was making a light.
The mammoth came and perched on the house.
He was so heavy (that) the house was shaking.
He was looking out near the fire.
to place in a horizontal position

morph.item: to place in a horizontal position

word.item: He thought (there were) people (lying in the place) where they had placed the two logs.
in a short while/not long after
It was not long (until) he got down on the bed and took hold of (it).
Then (the boys started) shooting at him.
They were shooting at him from both sides.
in a short while/not long after
He did not stand long (before) he fell.

morph.item: to place in a horizontal position

word.item: They placed the wood they had gathered all around him.
When they made a fire, the wood burned.
When it had burned up, his testicles burst.
When they burst, they splashed on a tree.
Wherever (one finds) a large knot (on) a tree in the woods, that is how it came to be.
